results.headline: Observe With Caution: She’s Not the Girl She Appears to Be (Not Even to Herself)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captive

results.summary_short: “Cautiva” is a sober, angry attempt to grapple with the horrors of Argentina’s recent history.

results.headline: Handmaiden to a Maestro and Midwife to His Symphony

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Copying Beethoven

results.summary_short: In “Copying Beethoven” Ed Harris proves an ideal substitute for the deaf, brooding composer, acting with a violent turbulence that sometimes floods the room.

results.headline: Rock, With a Gentle Undercurrent of Pubescent Yearning

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Linda Linda Linda

results.summary_short: “Linda Linda Linda” is an understated and disarmingly human tale of an all-girl band in the run-up to their school’s annual rock festival.

results.headline: Crispin Glover’s Underworld Freak Show

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Is It?

results.summary_short: Crispin Glover’s directorial debut is just as unclassifiable as he is.

results.headline: Jamaican Gangsters, With Drugs and a Contempt for Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shottas

results.summary_short: Stars from reggae and other musical worlds give acting a try in “Shottas,” a witless, misogynistic, gratuitously violent, drug-culture-worshiping film.

results.headline: Christ, With a Color Change

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Color of the Cross

results.summary_short: This low-budget re-imagining of Christ’s final days makes a big deal out of the relatively tame suggestion that Jesus was black.

results.headline: Looking at a Stalled World Through a Renault Windshield

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Magic Gloves

results.summary_short: Depression, drugs and professional stasis commingle in “The Magic Gloves,” a limp urban comedy not nearly as whimsical as its title.

results.headline: Contemplating Iraq’s Pain With a Cinematic Collage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Iraq in Fragments

results.summary_short: James Longley’s haunting, oblique film, “Iraq in Fragments,” presents a collage of images, sounds and characters in an intimate, partial portrait of an unraveling nation.

results.headline: From a Survivor of Nagasaki, Insight on the Nuclear Future

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Atomic Bomb

results.summary_short: “The Last Atomic Bomb” takes a deeply affecting look at the bombing of Nagasaki and its aftermath as seen through the eyes of a 70-year-old survivor named Sakue Shimohira.

results.headline: From India, a Courtesan’s Misfortune

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Umrao Jaan

results.summary_short: Weak dubbing and melodramatic overkill hamper this retelling of a historical Indian story, about the travails of a performing courtesan.

results.headline: The Darkest of Troubles in the Brightest of Colors

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Volver

results.summary_short: Pedro Almodóvar has made yet another picture that moves beyond camp into a realm of wise, luxuriant humanism.

results.headline: Washed Up in a World of Urban Vermin Intrigue

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flushed Away

results.summary_short: The first computer-animated feature to come from Aardman Animations is filled with exuberant and infectious silliness.

results.headline: From Kazakhstan, Without a Clue
results.display_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings Of America For Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Borat: Cultural Learnings Of America For Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan

results.summary_short: The brilliance of “Borat” is that its comedy is as pitiless as its social satire, and as brainy.

results.headline: A Straightforward Look at Our  Changing World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Warming

results.summary_short: This quietly persuasive documentary on the climate-change crisis presents both an abridged history and science lesson and a vital briefing on where we stand today.

results.headline: Five Strangers in a Dangerous Game of Cat-and-Mouse

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unknown

results.summary_short: This twisty thriller, which locks five men inside a dingy warehouse, features a whole lot of buildup, and a real letdown of a payoff.

results.headline: Can Neighborly Affection Rewire Sexuality?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Soap

results.summary_short: The directorial debut of Pernille Fischer Christensen is an anti-soap opera in the trappings of an old-fashioned sudsfest.

results.headline: Prejudice Blossoms When Neighbors Connect

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wondrous Oblivion

results.summary_short: Form and content fight to the death in Paul Morrison’s defiantly gauzy tale of racial friction in 1960s England.

results.headline: Swimming Through Life, With Tales to Tell

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deeper Than Y

results.summary_short: This very-low-budget documentary gives some aging swimmers at a YMCA in Manhattan a chance to tell their life stories and expound on the experience of growing old.

results.headline: Just a Hardy Bunch of Settlers Who Left America and Moved to California

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Commune

results.summary_short: "Commune," a breezy, informal history of a long-running California commune begun in the summer of 1968 and still in existence, offers the fascinating spectacle of observing people then and now.

results.headline: At Home With the Clauses, In-Laws and Elves Included
results.display_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause

results.summary_short: The third though probably not the last in the successful “Clause” franchise, this latest installment again stars Tim Allen as the Everyman turned Father Christmas.
